No. 1748-20/4 / ^ Dated the 26th May 1947 (D I have had a talk with Belgrave about the subject of your demi-official letter No# 772-S* dated the 30th April f 1947, with which you sent me a list of people you think of (I) Shaikh Salman and his sons# No small boys should be expected to dinner# (II) Shaikh Abdulla and one or two sons. All the sons of Shaikh Abdulla are bad lots and might be excluded# (III) Ali bin Khalifa, presumably Ali bin Khalifa bin Daij# (IV) Belgrave thinks that you visited Jabj£r bin Itfusallem at Hedd and that he might be invited, though we think he has gone pearling# I will find out# (V) Perhaps some of the local Indian merchants might be invited. For example, the Shaikh I^believe, regards Mr, Ashraf favourably# (VI) The numbers are small for a dinner to be giv^n by the Political Residaat# inviting to an Arab Dinner# My comments, which I think also represent Belgrave’s views correctly, are as follows*- Yours sincerely, 0/C The Hon’ble Lieut-Colonel W.R. Hay, C#S#I#, C.I.i2., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf Bahrain#Extract from a letter (No.c/899 dated 12.12.’37) from H. Weightman, Esq., I.C.3., Political Agent, Bahrain, to the Chief Local Representative, The Bahrain Petro leum company, Limited, Bahrain. xx XX XX It may be of assistance to inform you of the relative precedence accorded by Royal Warrant and by courtesy and local usage in the official community. \ This is as follows (1) The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, j His Highness the Shaikh of Bahrain. jj (2) The Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf. (3) Captains (by rank) in His Majesty's Navy. (4) The Political Agent. (5) The Adviser to the Bahrain Govt, (by courtesy) (6) The Secretary to the political Resident in the Persian Gulf, when in Bahrain. (7) Commander (by rank) in His Majesty’s Navy. The brothers and sons of His Highness the Shaikh are given positions by courtesy as circumstances may require, but on no occasion should they be accorded precedence over the Political Agent. No.C/683. political Agerufcy, Bahrain, The 11th June, 1947. Forwarded with compliments to: The Personal Assistant to the Hon’ble the policical Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain.

mods.abstract: Correspondence relating to etiquette:Letter to William Rupert Hay, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf commenting on a list of people to be invited to an 'Arab Dinner', following a discussion with Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, Adviser to the Bahrain Government.extract from a letter by Hugh Weightman, Political Agent, Bahrain, to the Chief Local Representative, Bahrain Petroleum Company, Bahrain, concerning relative precedence between British officials and the Khalifa [Āl Khalīfah] ruling family.
